Insects like the black soldier fly (BSF) have a symbiotic relationship with bacteria. Due to selective pressures like medicine and agriculture, though, some bacteria have developed antibiotic resistance (AR) genes. These AR genes can be directly shared with other bacteria, a process called vertical transmission. If BSF feed on waste containing AR genes, it is possible that larva and frass will contain them too.

Genetic adaptability within the fish to adapt to new food sources is something we can take advantage of as researchers, where we can introduce insect based diets and over time these can be more accepted and digested by fish.

The relevance of this paper to insect growers is that it provides evidence for the potential use of Hermetia illucens larvae meal as a prebiotic feed additive for rainbow trout. Insect growers may be interested in exploring the use of their insect products as a sustainable and environmentally friendly source of feed for aquaculture animals. The findings of this study suggest that insect meal from H. illucens larvae could positively affect the gut microbiota of rainbow trout and potentially improve their health and growth performance. This may be of interest to insect growers who are looking to expand their market to include the aquaculture industry.

A major component of population and functional genetics is comparing DNA sequence data with phenotypic (observable traits) data. For example, one line of insects might produce larger larvae than the rest. Identifying the genetics responsible allows for reproducibility and fine-tuning of this trait. One could insert or breed the large larvae genes into other populations, using markers identified by this research to guide the process. One might find that the large larvae gene comes with unacceptable tradeoffs, and research might uncover a downstream gene more specific to the phenotype and with less side effects. Manual collection of detailed, standardized phenotypes for a given sample continues to be important for the statistical analyses that identify candidate genes. Unfortunately, these experiments require trained labor and have the associated throughput limitations. This paper proposes a network based genomic selection program to find high-fitness genes, which is to say that the approach filters lots of sequencing information into statistical analyses to find which combination of genes lead to useful traits.
Increasing larval density will decrease development time but decrease adult survival, so depending on if larvae or adults are the aim for production, this can be adjusted.
More research needs to be done to look at how to keep up the food utilization of the fish when being fed BSF protein, as it was lower compared to using soybean.
As global temperatures increase, mass-reared insects must be insured a nutritionally rich diet to match physiological changes surrounding their metabolism.

Addition of seaweed up to a 50% inclusion was beneficial, and showed the plasticity of BSF larvae to accumulate lipid and water soluble compounds. Gaining a full understanding to how BSF larvae accumulate specific nutrients can be extremely beneficial to create very specific larvae as feed ingredients for various livestock.

Though it presents some ethical concerns, flightless black soldier flies have been explored for better containment during mass rearing. In addition to better production efficiency, flightlessness reduces the chance that domesticated BSF will escape and hybridize with local populations. This important because one regulatory barrier to the introduction of domesticated and genetically modified BSF in a region is concerns about foreign DNA mixing. Silkworms, a major commercial insect in the moth family, developed the flightless trait through millennia of selection. This paper describes how the fruit moth, a distant relative to the silkworm, responds to selection on flying ability.
This research could inform the further research into the role that these DMRT A2 and Hsp83 genes play in the gonad development of various insect species relevant to insects as food and feed.

Though this research was primarily conducted with the intent of generating novel pest control techniques, researching these male accessory gland (MAG) compounds in BSF could be beneficial to mini-livestock production. Not only could we gain a better understanding of BSF reproduction, but it is possible that we could identify molecules found within BSF MAG that induce beneficial phenotypic changes in females with respect to oviposition, egg development, etc. This information could potentially go towards developing novel dietary supplement to increase reproductively in a domesticated setting.

May want to investigate the use of insect probiotics as a way to offer protection for insects against viral pathogens. May want to investigate vaccines for insects against some of these viral pathogens.

This study found that feeding the laying hens BSF meal could enhance the enterocyte metabolism and gut homeostasis in laying hens, which can improve their health parameters. Specific blends could be created for different types of poultry to enahance their health

To reduce negative environmental impacts with the use of insect rearing, we need to be paying attention to the insect diets themselves, as well as how substrates or frass are being composted. Water use in insect diets are a major concern, as that is where the majority of water use is consumed during the process.

Insights into how bacterial interactions shape the microbiome variability in isogenic organisms could aid insect producers in understanding and potentially manipulating the microbiome assembly in insects. This understanding may contribute to developing probiotics or other interventions for insect rearing and health management.
May be able to develop some biological markers of insect health from the frass of IAB insects.
Higher carbohydrate nutrition may enable higher thermal tolerance, which can be adjusted for in high-temperature mass-rearing environments.
Finding rearing temperatures for a variety of insects can help optimize preferred reared insects and decrease pests in the facilities.

Transposable elements (TE) are small pieces of DNA that move around in a genome. They have long been associated with genetic disorders and disease, as they can break genes if they are inserted in the middle of one (among other problems). The authors of this paper explain, though, there is increasing evidence for the benefits of TEs in adaptive evolution. Little information is available on the potential role of TEs in domestication. This paper makes a case for the role of TEs in several important commercial traits. For example, increased developmental uniformity in silkworms or adaptation to different light cycles in corn. The silkworm (Bombyx mori) is arguably the only completely domesticated insect, so it is a good model to look at when making inferences about the future of other insects still in the process of domestication, like mealworm, cricket, and black soldier fly.

Beekeepers and producers involved in bee health and pollination services should be interested in this research on phage communities in honey bee gut microbiomes. The study reveals the complexity of phage communities, their diversity, and their potential impact on microbial dynamics within bees. Beekeepers may consider the implications of phage-host interactions for bee health and explore the possibility of using engineered phages for microbiome engineering, potentially contributing to improved bee health and pollination services.

Fatty acids are involved in growth, development and immune defense. Ongoing research is exploring the value of lauric acid supplementation in boiler chicken health, for example. While diet is a major factor in insect fat content, though, the production and storage of fat is also governed by genetic factors. Supplementation needs to be added in every batch, may involve costly or difficult to obtain materials, and creates one more variable to manage in the substrate. Though genetic modification can involve significant starting costs, from discovery research to implementation, the benefit of increased fatty acid synthesis is passed on many generations later. The risk/reward of either approach varies with each use case. If GMO is warranted, though, manipulation of Acyl carrier protein (ACP) is a promising route. The authors of this paper show how ACP, involved in fatty acid synthesis, affects key biological proccesses like size, survival, and egg laying.

The use of antibiotics has applied a selection force on aquatic bacteria where those that, by random chance, have genes giving resistance survive and reproduce. Bacteria can also directly transfer antibiotic resistance (AR) genes through a process called vertical transmission. This means that a bacterial line doesn’t need to have experienced penicillin, they just need to meet a bacterium that has. Coupled with a short life span and generation time sometimes measured in minutes, it is easy to see why antibiotic resistance is such a large problem. Insects are known sources of potentially pathogenic microbes. Those microbes may be sources of AR genes too. The goal for Black Soldier flies is a closed loop system where organic material is recycled. It is especially important that scientists can track which, if any, contaminants like AR genes can circulate.

Understanding how insect-associated bacteria influence vector competence for arboviruses is crucial for insect producers dealing with arbovirus-transmitting insects. Insights into the microbial mechanisms that reduce vector competence could potentially inform strategies to reduce disease transmission or modify insect microbiomes to limit arbovirus transmission.

This study showed that the nutritional composition and conversion are closely related to the source and composition of substrates, meaning we need to optimize the input of the feeding substrates to optimize larval composition.

Plants are adapting some defense mechanisms in rising temperatures, which has affected their nutritional composition and how insects feed on them, so those rearing insects on plants must be ready to adjust to these changes.

Epigenetics studies heritable (passed on to children) changes in gene expression without DNA sequence changes. DNA is wrapped in proteins so that it stays organized in cells, which can be tighter or looser to affect how much of a gene is expressed. Chemical groups can also be added to DNA directly to affect gene expression. This means, if one only looks at DNA sequences, they are likely to miss important information about the mechanism behind important traits. For example, in large studies across the animal kingdom, it was often found that domestication forces (which commercial insects experience) lead to stronger changes in gene expression than DNA. This paper reviews how epigenetic changes can lead to insecticide and climate change resistance, the latter of which is most useful for high-density insects that are prone to overheating.
Stable Isotope Analysis could be used, in addition to DNA analysis, to gain insight on the diet wild black black soldier fly populations as well as being used as an environmental surveillance tool.

As we still have a lot to learn about the extraorinary and nuanced behavioral and molecular immunilogical mechanisms of insects, we can turn to what we know about other organism in the anamal kingdom. Learning more about these processes in other animals could help us to create novel desease preventing techneqes in insect rearing facilities.

Epigenetics studies heritable (passed on to children) changes in gene expression without DNA sequence changes. DNA is wrapped in proteins so that it stays organized in cells, which can be tighter or looser to affect how much of a gene is expressed. Chemical groups can also be added to DNA directly to affect gene expression. This means, if one only looks at DNA sequences, they are likely to miss important information about the mechanism behind important traits. For example, in large studies across the animal kingdom, it was often found that domestication forces (which commercial insects experience) lead to stronger changes in gene expression than DNA. The authors investigate how the silkworm responds to heat and humidity stress with epigenetic changes. This paper is relevant to IAB interests because heat stress in high-density rearing is a common problem in commercial rearing. Epigenetics may be one more tool we can use to deal with it.
Any mealworm farmer knows the risks of pathogen spreading while rearing at high densities. tyhis is a great reading to broadly familiarize yourself with mealworm imune physiology.

MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are small pieces of RNA that don’t code for a protein. Instead, they influence the availability of protein coding RNAs, which adds another layer of regulation to protein production. Often, breeding for a particular trait will influence how much a protein is produced more than changes to amino acid sequence. To understand the full impacts of selection, it is important to track changes in non-coding RNAs in research. Also, because many key genes are highly networked, direct modifications could impose significant fitness costs, which shows the importance of more subtle miRNA-based trait manipulation. This paper describes development related miRNAs in the red flour beetle, which is in the same family as mealworms and superworms. The insights provided here lay the groundwork for future breeding or GMO experiments targeting optimal growth rates.

The study sheds light on the importance of microbiota on the growth and health of BSF larvae, which are used as biowaste recyclers and a source of animal proteins in the insect rearing industry. The results open up opportunities for the optimization of zootechnical properties in alternative animal protein production, biowaste revalorization, and recycling, highlighting the need to consider microbiota management strategies in insect rearing practices.
Crude oil from BSF contains AMPs (antimicrobial peptides) which can be used in other systems. more research needs to be done in this area and which pathogens/microbes can be reduced.

Domestication leads to changes, deliberate and accidental, to an organism’s genome. The sampling of a small number of organisms for mass rearing creates population bottlenecks that reduce population diversity. Humans often impose environmental conditions that are drastically different from the wild, which further limits available genetic material as selection favors a narrow set of traits. These changes are more complex than whole genome diversity losses, though. DNA goes through many steps to create a trait (DNA>RNA>Protein), each of which is regulated and can be acted on by domestication. It is important to understand how mass rearing affects insects at each level. This is true both for proactively managing potential risks to colony health and maximizing the benefits of domestication. In this paper, the authors show that gene expression diversity was lower in domesticated animals and plants like the silkworm, which is the oldest domesticated insect. Given that RNAseq (measures gene expresion) is cheaper than DNA sequencing, it may be a more feasible approach to colony monitoring. One could look at a few key markers rather than whole genome sequencing.

Heavy metals, especially Cadmium (Cd), can accumulate in black soldier fly larvae because of uptake from a contaminated waste. These metals are added to livestock feed to prevent diseases and promote growth in some countries, which are excreted with animal feces. Pre-consumer vegetable waste streams are more commonly discussed in black soldier fly (BSF) rearing substrates. Recycling manure is also viable, both for food production and waste management. Heavy metal contamination in pig feces is worse than other traditional livestock. Not only does this present a risk for crops and livestock that receive black soldier fly products, but a toxic substrate could have bad effects on the larvae themselves. This paper investigates how different larval densities affect the heavy metal concentration of frass.
Ensuring the integrity of the gut epithelium could make mass-reared insect colonies much more stable and resilient.

The study provides valuable insights into the potential use of phytochemicals and their effects on the gut microbiota of insects. Insect growers can potentially use this information to optimize the diet of their insects, particularly silkworms, for improved health and growth. The findings also highlight the importance of considering the role of intestinal microbiota in insect nutrition and health, and suggest the potential for the development of targeted strategies for promoting gut health in insect rearing.

The relevance of this research to insect producers is substantial, especially concerning their role in providing sustainable solutions for pest management and biocontrol. For insect producers, this study highlights opportunities to showcase the efficacy of their products, such as entomopathogenic fungi, bacteria, or viruses, as potential agents for combating forest insect pests. Understanding the interactions of these biological control agents with phytochemicals in forest ecosystems opens avenues for insect producers to emphasize the effectiveness of their offerings in mitigating ecological and economic damage caused by forest pests.
The quality of frass is just as important as the diet for the larvae. Product in versus product out.

fish fed with diets containing BSFLM had improved muscle texture and body color, which can increase the marketability. They used partially degreased larvae, which doesn't exactly describe how defatted these may be, but fully defatting may allow a higher inclusion.

Though we do not commercially farm ants for food and feed on a large commercial scales, better understanding fatty acid metabolism and the role of Acyl-Coenzyme A Dehydrogenase in that process could help us to improve the methods by which we grow other insects.

Black Soldier flies obviously have a variety of requirements when it comes to reproduction and light availability,preferring certain wavelengths for mating to ensue for example. Understanding the role that light may or may not play in the reproduction of other dipterans will lay the groundwork for future BSF specific studies.
Having a combination of insect frass and commercial fertilizers had the best result for crop growth and pathogen resistance. More research can be done here for different combination ratios.
More research is needed with this species of fish to ensure it can be produced economically on a large scale.

The investigation into the impact of insect herbivory on microbial colonizers in plant communities sheds light on how herbivory influences microbial communities in plants. This information might be relevant for insect growers concerned with understanding the impact of insect herbivory on plant health and associated microbial dynamics.

Swill was an excellent rearing substrate for BSF larvae, however more research can be done on the nutritional and chemical properties of these diets. The poor performing diets can also be looked at to see if additions can be included to increase the digestibility for BSF.
May want to consider evolutionary studies into to IAB species to see what genes are conserved and/if interactions with microbes shaped evolutionary behavior.

Silkworms were first domesticated thousands of years ago, before the founding of Rome and the Great Wall of China. Modern insect agriculturists have much to gain from observation of well tested sericulture practices (silkworm breeding). Modern silk production offers interesting insights too. Genetically modified silkworms have produced multicolored or glowing silk. They are being explored for mass production of collagen, amino acids, and bioactive compounds such as human platelet derived growth factor (PDGF), which is associated with wound healing. One problem is that silkworms, for the most part, can only eat Mulberry leaves. Similar genetic modifications can be made to generalists like many CEIF species. It may be possible to transform low quality waste into highly valued biomolecules, all at large scales and using mostly unskilled labor (after the organisms have been designed).

Silkworms have been domesticated for many centuries. The silkworm industry, and its model organism, is useful for informing best practices in the management and analysis of modern commercial insects. Silkworms breeding programs have led to major increases in silk production, but, at the time of writing, very little was known about underlying mechanisms. The authors of this paper discuss improved silkworm lines through heterosis, which has been described in Chinese literature as far back as the 1600s. Heterosis, also known as hybrid vigor, describes the process by which some combinations of parents lead to offspring that are more fit than either parent. The authors use gene expression and proteomics (studying all proteins) to explain how crosses between different strains led to more silk yield. Briefly, the end goal is to take what is known about “good” combinations of genes and apply it to genetically modified products.

Understanding the intricate relationships between plant-soil feedback (PSF), rhizosphere microbiomes, and plant-insect interactions showcased in this study holds significance for insect producers involved in biocontrol and crop management. The differential effects of shoot and root herbivores on the rhizosphere microbiome, impacting plant growth, defense mechanisms, and resistance against pests like Delia radicum larvae, offer valuable insights for producers seeking sustainable pest management strategies. This research illuminates the complex interplay between plant health, soil conditions, and herbivore interactions, potentially aiding insect producers in devising more targeted and eco-friendly approaches for pest control in agricultural settings.

Insects like the black soldier fly (BSF) have a symbiotic relationship with bacteria. Due to selective pressures like medicine and agriculture, though, some bacteria have developed antibiotic resistance (AR) genes. These AR genes can be directly shared with other bacteria, a process called vertical transmission. If BSF feed on waste containing AR genes, it is possible that larvae and frass will contain them too.

May want to evaluate the effects of this amended frass on several kinds of agricultural plants that are grown in high volume as this would be a good source of potential revenue. Potential crops to evaluate are beans, grains, corn, and soy.
The heat tolerance of wild insects may be changing, which could allow for adjusted rearing temperatures that would be more cost-efficient.

This review paper provides valuable insights for insect producers by highlighting market opportunities, emphasizing the sustainability and nutritional benefits of edible insects, and addressing challenges that need to be overcome for wider acceptance and integration into the food industry.
BSF are a good alternative protein source for other animals, including guinea pigs. While there were no negative impacts, the overall FCR was reduced, which is a cost reduction in the feed.
Mass rearing of some insects can be supplemented by higher temperatures and longer photoperiods than found in their natural environment.
Might want to consider a parallel study in which black soldier fly and commercial feed is used to establish parallel comparison of health, breed stock and feed conversions.
May want to consider different methods of breeding reduce occurrence of antibiotic resistance genes.

Male and female adult flies use their resources differently, and the abdominal windows can be a good age predictor for males. There could be a selection happening within colonies, where males are trying to find females with fuller windows to mate with.

Many insect agriculture species have poorly defined genomes, given their novelty, so a lot of projects must begin with characterizing their genes, sometimes relying on reference genomes of the closest relative with a complete assembly. The basic way biologists identify genes in a new species has been the same for the last two decades. Sequence data is piped into hidden markhov models like Augustus (which at the time of writings is pretty much all the center uses) and takes hints from what we know about existing genes in other species. These HMMs don’t do well outside of the species it was designed for, which is a problem for insect agriculture. The closest related species on the web browser Augustus to the black soldier fly, for example, is the 200 million year distant fruit fly, which is why pipelines like BRAKER add pretraining steps. This paper is interesting because it uses AI (a kind of recurrent neural network called long-short term memory) to annotate large genomes using only DNA sequences. For now, Helixer doesn’t seem to be a perfect substitute for older methods. The landscape of machine learning is rapidl

Insect’s reared as mini-livestock are prone to inbreeding. It is important to understand the effects of inbreeding on criteria that impact yield such as mating. Males becoming less attractive to females as a result of inbreeding could potentially lead to economic losses for insect farmers moving forward.

Since larval thermal tolerance is higher than prepupal or pupal, it is important to keep larvae in their same age group so high counts of larvae and larval activity do not overheat the prepupae or pupae.

This study showed that mealworm meals did not negatively affect microbial stability, and can be included at either 2 or 5% in the hens diet. Higher digesta viscosity may indicate slower passage through digestive tract.

Not all traits involved in commercial insect production are heritable, which is the ability for a trait to be passed down genetically. While many traits in insects are determined by their genetics, there are also many traits that are influenced by environmental factors such as temperature, rearing density, and feeding substrate. When a trait is affected by a combination of these factors, it can be difficult to determine which is most important to focus on. By studying the genetic basis of traits and their heritability, scientists can develop more accurate and effective breeding strategies. The authors in this paper define the mechanistic basis of food preference and lipid deposition (fat stores) in crickets more clearly. They show which traits are more likely to be affected by breeding programs and which ones we should alter with feed trials.

Understanding the diversity and interactions of viruses in insects is important for insect management programs, as viruses can have significant impacts on insect populations. Metagenomics analysis can aid in identifying viral strains present in insect populations, which can inform management strategies. Additionally, understanding the interactions between viruses and the insect's microbiome, as well as host antiviral immune pathways, can lead to the development of new methods for controlling insect populations.
More studies need to be done on this and adding other IAB insect species may yield important results that can increase health and feed conversion ratios.

Food waste mixed with chicken feed allowed for moisture to be properly controlled, reducing maintenance issues within the bins and produced large larvae with a faster growth rate. Research needs to be done to look at the minimum amounts of these MCCMs to include to minimize costs in producing insects.

Behavioral changes in response to light of BSF plays a role in copulation and oviposition. This paper sets the precedence for differential expression in response to light and could serve as a framework for similar research with BSF of other farmed insects.

The rearing substrate of the larvae is extremely important in yielding stable LA content. This can be a challenge when waste streams are used as feed. More studies need to be conducted into creating homogenous waste streams with a standard nutritional composition as feed.
These findings can be a valuable resource for selecting insect reference genes for gene expression studies in various tissues and experimental conditions.
May want to explore if the IAB insects can be used as potential tools for insect control and if they can be inoculated with bacteria that can confer protection for agricultural products.

The examination of gut microbiomes in different bee species, including Xylocopa carpenter bees, and the identification of specific bacterial lineages might provide insights into the gut microbiome composition of different bee species. This knowledge could be useful for insect growers studying the microbiomes of bees and their potential implications for bee health.
Reivew paper on frass as fertilizer, microbes were beneficial for the plants for growth and uptake of nutrients.

Fishmeal can be completely replaced with cricket meal for quials and will increase egg production and quality, however research can go into how we can stablilize the thickness of the eggshell for transportation reasons.
May want to consider if any behavior alteration can contribute to agricultural success in insects.

This study provides insights into the importance of gut microbiota in termites and how microbial communities are assembled during termite diversification. The findings highlight the role of both vertical and horizontal transmission in shaping the gut microbiota of termites, which has significant implications for the rearing of termites in insect farms. Insect growers can use this information to understand the role of gut microbiota in termites and develop strategies to maintain or manipulate the microbiota for improved growth and health of termites.
Some ingredients in the feed for BSF may inhibit growth/development. Lignin digestibility in BSF should be considered.

The study explores Wolbachia and the microbiome of Tabanus nigrovittatus (greenhead). Two supergroups of Wolbachia were identified, A and B, in the greenhead population. The microbiome analysis revealed a diverse composition, with Gammaproteobacteria being predominant, and the presence of Spiroplasma in varying frequencies. The study suggests an association between Wolbachia presence and higher Alphaproteobacteria representation in the microbiomes, indicating an impact on the host's microbiome composition.

This study showed that the use of frass from the black soldier fly can be used as a feed ingredient for channel catfish and actually possibly benefit the fish in growth and disease resistance. Keep in mind that the original substrate is vital to achieve these results.

For insect growers, the relevance of inbreeding depression lies in its potential negative impact on the health and productivity of reared insect populations. Breeding closely related insects can lead to reduced fitness and reproductive success, affecting traits important for biological control, pollination, and food production. To maintain thriving insect populations, growers should adopt strategies like controlled outbreeding, maintaining larger breeding groups, and employing selective breeding to mitigate the adverse effects of inbreeding and ensure the success of their insect-based endeavors.
This was an in vitro study, focusing on modeling. This should be actually validated through in vivo methods with live animal models to solidify findings.

Good genetics is an important part of a successful organism, but DNA is only the beginning of the complex web of biological processes that are responsible for an organism's traits. The central dogma describes how DNA becomes RNA, RNA becomes protein, and proteins act together to create anything from intestines to neural tissue. Each step is regulated and informed by environmental conditions. Ideally, an insect will respond to new environmental conditions by changing the activity of these steps. For example, a company may wish to expand to a drier location and their insects have been adapted to high humidity. In some cases, the results could be disastrous, leading to delayed or absent oviposition. In others, the organism might upregulate a gene associated with water conservation and thrive in the new facility. We call the change of traits in response to a different environment, with the same genetics, “phenotypic plasticity”. The authors of this paper study phenotypic plasticity of the field cricket. They show that, in the short term, high-level behavioral plasticity can be just as effective for survival as modifying lower-level responses like heat shock proteins or receptors. On the other hand, if the goal is to breed for a certain trait, behavioral responses may slow down evolution.

Understanding the complex interactions between insects and their microbiota is crucial for the development of effective strategies for managing insect pests and for promoting beneficial insects. The use of Drosophila melanogaster as a model organism for studying the evolution and function of the immune system and microbiota can provide valuable insights into these interactions. The findings from this research can be applied to the development of novel insect control methods that target the microbiome, as well as the identification of beneficial microbes that can be used for improving insect health and productivity.
The rearing substrate of the larvae is very important as it will alter the microbiota of the larvae, which can in turn alter whichever animal you are feeding these larvae to.
Larvae rearing in hotter climates needs to be monitored closely to ensure that temperatures do not exceed thermal limits for the species.

Honeybees are crucial for pollination in agriculture, and their decline has raised concerns about the sustainability of crop production. Understanding the role of microbial symbionts in honeybee health can help protect and improve honeybee populations, which can have a positive impact on insect agriculture. The use of insect symbionts as a tool for protecting beneficial insects can also be relevant to insect agriculture practices, where maintaining the health of beneficial insects is important for pest control and crop production.

The research explores the impact of different diets on the physiology of Drosophila melanogaster, particularly in the context of microbiome studies. By conducting a meta-analysis of diets used in fly microbiome research, the authors highlight the variations in nutritional content across laboratories. To assist the research community, they introduce the Drosophila Dietary Composition Calculator (DDCC), a web-based tool to determine the nutritional composition of specific diets. The study underscores the importance of standardizing fly diets to improve the consistency and interpretation of research outcomes.

The study highlights the potential of Hermetia illucens larvae meal as a replacement for soybean diet in laying hens. The findings suggest that insect-based diets could modify the gut microbiota of animals, which could have implications for their overall health and performance. This information could be useful for insect rearing industries that produce insects as a source of feed for animals and humans. Understanding the effects of insect-based diets on the gut microbiota and SCFAs production could contribute to the development of more sustainable and nutritious animal feed.

Under natural conditions, the substrate in which BSF females oviposit (lay eggs) is the same one that their larvae will develop on. The “mother knows best” hypothesis suggests that the flies oviposit on a surface that has what the larvae need (nutrient profile, microbiome, moisture). Under artificial conditions, where mating is controlled, eggs are often transferred from the oviposition site to different container for development. The fly has no way of knowing this is the case, though, and must decide whether to lay eggs based on the environment it is currently in. Oviposition acceptance (OA) and oviposition preference (OP) are complicated behavioral traits and role of genetics in these behaviors are not well established.

This paper can help to inform folks rearing mealworms in large scale to the importance of sanititation and provides a novel metric (using selective growth mediums to assess Serratia) for assessing infectious pressures in their own rearing facilities.

Understanding the role of microbial communities in insects is essential for insect growers. Mosquitoes are notorious for transmitting human pathogens, and their microbial communities play a crucial role in this process. The development of an approach to transfer entire microbial communities between mosquito cohorts will aid in studying the factors underlying microbiota acquisition, assembly, and function in mosquitoes under controlled conditions. This will provide insights into the role of microbiota in mosquito growth, survival, reproduction, and pathogen transmission, which can be used to develop strategies to control mosquito populations and reduce the transmission of human pathogens.

For insect producers, understanding the complex functional profiles of arthropod microbiomes can provide insights into optimizing insect health and production. Recognizing how microbial communities adapt and evolve within insect hosts can inform strategies to enhance rearing conditions, improve disease resistance, and promote beneficial interactions. This research can guide producers in developing targeted approaches for microbiome manipulation, contributing to sustainable and efficient insect production systems.

May be of use to the IAB because of Apis mellifera is a large commercial species of bees in China with potential to be a revenue source in the united states though pollination services. May want to evaluate the gut microbiome at different developmental stages within IAB insect populations. Additionally, as microbiome can affect host behavior, successful modulation of the microbiome may increase insect husbandry and lower insect stress.
Mealworm may be a slightly better alternative protein source for this specific fish (seabass), compared to BSF meal to be able to increase the inclusion rate.

May want to investigate the role ontogenesis plays in the bacterial diversity in IAB species of insects. Can these species be modulated to reduce contamination risk? Can microbiome be modulated to increase feed conversion values?

Further research can be done into how different stressors can affect heat tolerance in insects. Since this study observed that bees were not heat priming to improve their thermal tolerance; trying to improve short-term thermal tolerance levels with heat exposure may not be as efficient as fortifying insects against heat through other factors like nutrition.

This research has implications for producers relying on corbiculate bees (honey bees, bumble bees, stingless bees) for pollination services. The study explores the dynamic evolutionary history of the microbiota in these important pollinators. Understanding the distinct gut communities across different host species and the influence of host ecology can inform practices that support the development and maintenance of specialized microbiomes. Producers involved in bee-dependent agriculture should consider the microbiome diversity of corbiculate bees in managing and promoting pollination services.

Through many aquaculture studies, many times the full-fat BSF feed tends to result in a lower inclusion rate to limit negative side effects. The process of nutritional programming through broodstock feeding can increase these inclusion rates. More studies can go into this for other species for a few generations.

The main insect model used for genetics work is Drosophila (fruit fly). Beetles, like the mealworm, contain over 500,00 species and are separated from the fruit fly by 240 million years (ballpark) of evolution. The red flour beetle (T. castaneum), which is in the same family as mealworms, is a promising alternative to the fruit fly for IAB and researchers invested in a broader range of commercial insects. This paper reviews the state of red flour beetle genetics research and makes a compelling case for their use as a model insect. They also show how genetic data gathered from this beetle may offer more insights into gene function than the fruit fly, because flies have some traits that are unique to that order.
Optimizing mass rearing protocols  can greatly increase output.
They determined the optimal dietary inclusion of BSFL for broiler chickens to be 540g/kg DM, which would reduce feed costs and not negatively impact growth or quality of chicken.

The genetic landscape of the Black Soldier Fly (BSF) is poorly described in literature. Even with the recent boom of scientific interest, most studies concern feed trials, microbial interactions, and nutritional/chemical profiles. This paper concerns the microRNA profile of the black soldier fly (BSF). MicroRNAs are small single-stranded RNA molecules that don’t code for a protein. Instead, many miRNAs regulate gene expression. Other insect genomics studies have shown that miRNA regulates biological and behavioral functions at different life stages. By understanding microRNA expression in commercial insects like BSF, we will better understand how they adapt to the changes in their environment during mass rearing.

Transposable elements (TEs) are pieces of DNA that break off from their position on a genome and insert themselves somewhere else, like a virus might. TEs can introduce new functions and studies show that they are major drivers of adaptation. On the other hand, these TEs can insert themselves in the middle of a gene and break them. They can increase or decrease the expression of key genes, leading to potentially negative outcomes. This is why organisms have developed responses to silence the expression of the mobile elements. The authors of this paper show that effective management of TEs is associated with longevity in termite. This could be relevant in two ways. First, while longevity is not necessarily something that’s needed in insects harvested for feed, TE silencing may improve fitness in the longer-lived species like mealworms. Second, longevity may be a goal for those insects selected for egg laying. Consider that the difference between a reproducing queen and a worker is largely driven by differences in gene expression, not genotype. Physiological changes, like enlarged abdomens and the production of fertility-associated lipids and proteins coincide with increased gene expression, during which TE expression must be more tightly managed. It could be possible to breed a longer-lived, perpetually fecund line of BSF, given studies that have already shown evidence of multiple paternity.

Using restaurant waste as a food source for the BSF larvae provides a good balance of nutrients that produced the largest larvae with better conversion rates and highest protein contents. More research can be done to increase the calcium and phosphorous levels in the larvae.

The findings of the study suggest that full-fat black soldier fly larvae meal can be used in brown trout diets at levels of up to 20%, which may provide a new market for insect growers producing black soldier fly larvae.

This is a great review on many facets of the pet food industry and how different pets can consume insect feed within their diets, showing differences in palatibility, digestibility of essential amino acids, and sustainability.

Traditional marker-based methods for detection of variation are inexpensive but miss chromosomal structural variations (SVs). Some existing tools for SV detection can’t capture inversions and translocations. Others can only make predictions if a gene is directly impacted by the SV. Modern interpretations of noncoding DNA have long since moved passed the idea that they are filler or “junk DNA” and are associated with important regulatory functions and the maintenance of chromosomal structure. The black soldier fly is estimated to have 66% repeat content, which does not code for proteins, and over half of the mealworm genome contains a single, massive repeat. There is a great need for the ability to both quantify differences in SVs, coding or otherwise, and connect those differences to a phenotype. The authors of this paper are concerned with human disease, but phenotype can mean any other trait- fast growth, immune function, flavor, nutrition.

Many discussions on black soldier fly nutrition come from the perspective of identifying an optimal substrate profile in order to maximize performance. In many cases, such as BSF reared on waste streams, an idealized diet may not be achievable. Another route is to adapt the organism to an economically viable food source, either through breeding or direct genetic modification. The ability to change observable traits (phenotypes) in response to a changing environment is called “phenotypic plasticity”. In many animals, males and females have different phenotypic plasticity in response to nutritional changes. The authors of this paper show that female fruit flies grow bigger, faster than males and the insulin pathway is involved.
This comprehensive review is a great tool for industry members and academics interested in optimizing desired traits within domesticated insect populations.

Insect behavior is guided by odor cues. It affects everything from mating to diet preference. Olfaction (smelling) involves many receptors, transport proteins, and associated neurons, which means that the metabolic cost of odor sensitivity can be high. Like with most expensive traits, they tend to build up mutations when selection stops favoring them so strongly. The controlled environment of mass rearing has a less complex odor profile, and food/mates are often a few centimeters away, so domestication is likely to result in insects with much different (probably less sensitive) odor detection systems. Studying domestication related olfactory changes can be useful for building fundamental knowledge. Perhaps we can engineer a line of insects that become ravenous when they smell a particular kind of waste. Or maybe an insect can be engineered to mate only when a particular odor enters its containers, allowing for precise life cycle control. This paper describes olfactory related genes in the fruit fly, which has a long history of lab rearing. The insights reported here are likely to translate with other domesticated insect agriculture species.

The queensland fruit fly is a pest in Australia. It is reared in mass quantities for sterile insect technique, which is a process in which sterile males are released in the wild for population control. Evolutionarily, these flies are very distant to other commercial insects like the black soldier fly or cricket. Practically, they are very similar. A small number are sampled from the wild, they experience strong artificial selection in lab/industry rearing, and their population explodes in number as reproduction is taken over by humans. Domesticated organisms often perform better than their wild counterparts- as long as artificial conditions don’t change and performance is evaluating the same traits that breeding programs act on. Unfortunately, selection can lead to negative changes that aren’t easily observed or take many generations to show themselves. For example, without sequencing, population diversity losses might not lead to observable problems for several generations. Then a pathogen spreads across a rearing facility and, because the insects’ immune systems are so similar, entire colonies must be discarded. This paper discusses the fitness changes in 100+ generation Queensland fruit flies (about 20 years if repeated with mealworms). It provides yet more evidence for the benefits of genetic monitoring and preventative maintenance in colony care.

The power of artificial selection is obvious in the difference between a chihuahua and a great Dane. Consider that kale, broccoli, and cabbage are derived from the same plant, each selected for a different trait and bred for many generations. Some traits are easy to measure, like body size or growth time, but even these “simple” traits are built upon many interacting proteins. To complicate the problem, many genes are passed on in blocks of DNA (recombination). If one selects for a gene involved in egg laying, they might also get a hitchhiking gene involved in wingspan, simply because it’s physically close in the fly’s DNA. Finally, there are often tradeoffs when selecting a useful trait. For example, a larger larval size might require more development time. Understanding fitness tradeoffs is key to the development of successful breeding programs for BSF. This paper shows that you can get flies to deposit eggs early, the tradeoff being reduced adult lifespan (which is short in BSF anyway).

A major component of population and functional genetics is comparing DNA sequence data with phenotypic (observable traits) data. For example, one line of insects might produce larger larvae than the rest. Identifying the genetics responsible allows for reproducibility and fine-tuning of this trait. One could insert or breed the large larvae genes into other populations, using markers identified by this research to guide the process. One might find that the large larvae gene comes with unacceptable tradeoffs, and research might uncover a downstream gene more specific to the phenotype and with less side effects. Finally, it is unlikely that a given trait happened upon a perfect optimum for mass rearing. Perhaps it would be more advantageous if a receptor bound a little bit better, or if the gene was expressed a little bit less. These are much easier to affect when we can point to a specific promoter or regulator. Manual collection of detailed, standardized phenotypes for a given sample continues to be important for the statistical analyses that identify candidate genes. Unfortunately, these experiments require trained labor and have the associated throughput limitations. Larger sample size gives more statistical power, which means better results. This paper suggests a “precision phenotyping” approach will improve the speed and standardization of data collection.

The article explores the relationship between metamorphosis and microbiota in insects, emphasizing the challenges and opportunities faced during this developmental process. Metamorphosis poses unique constraints on maintaining symbiotic relationships, as the larval environment undergoes radical changes, exposing microbes to new conditions and immunological challenges. Some insects retain the same symbiont throughout life stages but may relocate it within different tissues, while others harbor distinct microbial communities in larvae and adults, adapting to shifts in diet or habitat. This flexibility offers advantages over insects with less adaptable associations between life stages. Microbes have been found to influence metamorphosis by protecting against pathogens, supplying essential nutrients for adult development, and regulating pupation cues across various insect taxa. However, microbial associations in many families and orders of Holometabola remain unexplored, leaving room for further discoveries on the intricate relationship between metamorphosis and microbiota in the evolutionary context of animal development.

Phenotypic plasticity is the ability for an organism with the same genotype to respond in different ways, depending on their environment. For example, normally large larvae might be smaller if reared in a dense, nutrient deprived environment. The question is, how does the body “know” that its environment is different? What specific pathways are up or downregulated to achieve smaller size, or any other adaptation? How can we create larvae that grow faster and larger on available substrates? Unraveling these questions is crucial to engineering an idealized insect. Single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs or SNVs) are relatively easy to quantify with advances in sequencing. Unfortunately, these SNPs do not account for all the ways organisms manifest new traits. The authors of this paper focus on inversions. Traditional marker-based detection often falls short of capturing this variation because, when sequencing reads are mapped to a reference genome, their orientation and alignment are based on the reference sequence. This means inversions, which reverse the original chromosome structure, can be overlooked or misinterpreted as mismatches or gaps, rather than recognized as structural variations. The authors describe methods by which inversions can be reliably characterized, advocating graph-based pangenome, and report on at least 19 cases of inversions associated with adaptation and commercially useful traits in cash crops.

Domestication leads to changes, deliberate and accidental, to an organism’s genome. The sampling of a small number of organisms for mass rearing creates population bottlenecks that reduce population diversity. Humans often impose environmental conditions that are drastically different from the wild, which further limits available genetic material as selection favors a narrow set of traits. The process of domestication is often understood from the context of successful domesticates like dogs and cows, but the authors of this paper show that the vast majority of species fail to adapt. The big three insect agriculture species (BSF, cricket, mealworm) were selected in part because they perform well in human conditions. It is important to note, though, that dogs had more than 10,000 years of selection to get where they are today. By refining a generalized understanding of domestication, one can improve upon the traits granted by natural selection and ensure that a species of interest becomes a successful domesticate.

One subject of increasing controversy is the origin of the black soldier fly. Scientific consensus is that the BSF originated in the new world and very recently spread to the rest of the globe. Recent mitochondrial data call this into question, with the migration and branching of Old-World black soldier flies predicted to have occurred at least several million years ago- long before the evolution of homo sapiens. In a similar vein, early sightings of the black soldier fly in Europe suggested that it was introduced by human trade and migration in the 20th century. This paper reports on an alleged black soldier fly larva that was found in the tomb of a 16th century Italian princess, which would place the BSF in Europe at least four centuries prior. This sample has not been sequenced, which could be useful both to positively ID the specimen as BSF and to gain more insight into the black soldier fly’s historical demographics and genetic adaptations. Such information is crucial for improving BSF breeding and management, ultimately enhancing the productivity and sustainability of insect agriculture

Invertebrates lack the sophisticated adaptive immune system of vertebrate agriculture species like pigs, chickens, and cow. This means that they rely heavily on innate immunity, and antimicrobial peptides (AMPs) are one of the most important molecules in that system. Insects also rely on mutualistic bacteria, and AMPs can damage the insect’s own cells. Evolution favors a balance between too much activity, destroying the host and “good” bacteria, and too little, making them vulnerable to pathogens. The authors of this paper focus on a single fruit fly amp, Diptericin, and show how evolution has impacted it. In their introduction, they describe cases where insects that transition to more sterile environments partially or completely lose immune function. This is especially relevant to insect agriculture where, at the very least, the kind of pathogens encountered in commercial rearing are likely to be different from the wild. It is important to understand how we might be inadvertently promoting risks to colony health. Conversely, by leveraging mechanistic insights into AMP adaptation, we may be able to enhance disease tolerance through genomic breeding or through genetic modification. After all, each insect species or population is exposed to a unique environment and will likely be uniquely well-equipped to handle a specific range of pathogens.

This study explored the composition and establishment of microbiomes associated with eggs of the Southern green stinkbug, Nezara viridula (L.). Researchers employed high-throughput amplicon sequencing and quantitative PCR to investigate the microbiome of egg masses from natural populations in Belgium and Italy, as well as to analyze eggs at different developmental stages from laboratory strains. Results revealed that eggs from ovaries lacked bacteria, suggesting bacterial colonization occurred post-oviposition. The bacterial diversity of deposited eggs was notably low, with minimal changes observed in bacterial composition and density over time, implying limited bacterial growth. Notably, a Pantoea-like symbiont, previously identified in the midgut of N. viridula, was consistently present at high densities in most samples, indicating its dominance within the egg-associated microbiome. Furthermore, some eggs contained a Sodalis symbiont, previously unreported in N. viridula populations. Overall, the study concludes that the microbiome associated with N. viridula eggs is characterized by low diversity and is predominantly dominated by a few specific symbiotic bacteria, notably the Pantoea-like symbiont, suggesting its importance in the ecology of N. viridula eggs.

Reference genomes are the backbone of modern genetics work. High quality assemblies lead to better prediction of gene structure, a better understanding of the species demographic history, and offer a resource for functional genomics work. For example, the design of candidate regions for CRISPR/Cas9-based genetic modifications necessitates an understanding of the genome's topography to minimize off-target effects. The authors of this paper constructed a genome assembly using a novel technique known as Omni-C, which is less biased than Hi-C in its selection of regions due to the restriction enzymes it employs, to investigate chromosomal structure. Their final product was lower quality than the black soldier fly reference assembly, but still better than most other non-model insects. Also, insights might be gained from differences between these genomes. The NCBI reference came from the Sheppard strain, from North America, while the authors of this paper sourced BSF reared in Taiwan. Recent mitochondrial evidence suggests that Asian BSF occupy a separate lineage, so it is possible that this assembly contains variants not found in others.

Many commercial insects are marketed as a way of recycling food. Food waste streams aren’t homogenous, though, meaning that the insect is expected to eat spent beer grains with the same efficiency that it eats liquified tomatoes. Commercial insects are usually taken from the wild and domesticated, a process where humans control breeding and living conditions. The growing consensus on domestication is that it leads to a loss of genetic diversity. Having a genetically diverse population of black soldier flies means that there are many individuals that, by random chance, are better or worse at processing a certain kind of waste. At the time of writing, there weren’t many studies on the role, specifically, that diversity plays in ecological interactions and how it might affect an insect’s fitness. Will a genetically diverse population be able to take advantage of a mixed waste stream? The answer is unclear for BSF, but there are some fitness advantages in the case of the seed beetle.

When wild species are introduced to a laboratory environment, changes are often observed in genetic diversity, gene expression, and microbiome composition. Not all genetic changes are bad, and some are deliberately selected for, but reduction in diversity can reduce fitness in species undergoing mass rearing. In addition, introduction of artificial diets (like Gainsville) can disrupt the microbiome, which is especially bad for insects, like the black soldier fly, which rely on symbiotic bacteria for survival and health. Unlike many other species, Drosophila suziki (fruit fly) has thrived in lab rearing. So, why does one organism do better than another when placed in a new environment? If CEIF can find the answer, perhaps it can be applied to existing stock through genetic modification or changes in rearing practices.

Silkworms are a good resource for best practices, based on this history, but they are also good examples of what happens to insects under modern breeding programs. Heat shock proteins (HSPs) are molecular chaperones organized into 5 major families by molecular weight (HSP 60, 70,90, and 100 plus small HSPs). They were first observed in the context of heat stress but have since been associated with a variety of conditions like UV light, cold, and wound healing. HSPs are conserved (don’t change quickly) throughout all species and often work by helping proteins maintain their shape. They are critical both for the development of insects and for their survival in stressful environments, such as those encountered in mass rearing conditions.

In general, inbreeding is associated with a decrease in genetic diversity, increase in harmful recessive traits, and decrease in population fitness. On the other hand, the tendency of inbreeding to increase homozygosity (same version of a gene from both parents) can concentrate the “bad” genes in a subset of individuals. If many children are produced, and the sacrifice of some of them isn’t a problem, inbreeding can potentially be used to screen out low quality genes. It is the opinion of the writer that, overall, more harm is done than good, but it is important to recognize results that contradict expectations. This study of the red flour beetle, an important insect model, found that the beetle's microbiome is derived from flour-acquired microbes and varies depending on resource availability and density. The study also found that the beetle gains multiple fitness benefits from its microbiome, such as higher fecundity, egg survival, and lifespan, as well as reduced cannibalism. These findings suggest that maintaining a healthy microbiome in reared insects can improve their performance and productivity. Additionally, the study found that the microbiome is not essential for beetle survival and development under any tested conditions, suggesting that manipulating the microbiome of reared insects may be a viable strategy for optimizing insect production. Overall, this study provides valuable insights into the complex relationship between insects and their microbiomes, and can aid insect growers in developing strategies to optimize their rearing practices.

A population bottle neck is a rapid loss of diversity due to a reduction in population size- the same thing that happens every time a small number of insects are removed from the wild population to start a production line. Population genetics work is effective for measuring inbreeding or predicting bottlenecks when they have already occurred. What you get is a snapshot of the current population state and, if you are lucky, enough information to work backwards in time. The authors of this paper use computer modeling to simulate what would happen to an imaginary population under many different conditions. The projections don’t say much about a specific group or production strain, but they can help scientists understand more about the biological processes involved. This allows for generalizations that can be improved upon as more strain specific data is acquired. The other advantage of computer simulations is that they are cheaper and allow you to observe a number of generations that would be impractical in the real world. For example, repeating the experiment in this study for live mealworms would take 333 years of continuous breeding.

The study suggests that dysbiotic states induced by nutrient-poor diets can lead to reduced insect weight and size and longer developmental stages, which could have negative implications for insect growers' production efficiency. Additionally, the study highlights the importance of maintaining stable and well-connected bacterial interactomes in the gut microbiome, which could be relevant for developing strategies to improve the health and productivity of insects in commercial settings.

Single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs or SNVs), which represent places on a genome that differ by one A, C, T, or G between samples, are relatively easy to quantify with advances in sequencing. Unfortunately, these SNPs do not account for all the ways organisms manifest new traits. Large chromosomal sections of a genome may break off, duplicate, or appear in reverse order. DNA structures called mobile or transposable elements break from their position on a genome and reinsert themselves somewhere else. Traditional marker-based detection of variation has trouble capturing this information, even where only SNP data is needed, because it relies on linearly mapping DNA to a single reference that is unlikely to represent an entire species. This paper describes pangenomics, which compares whole genomes with each other, and how it is already being applied in crop research to solve problems that marker-based approaches fall short in addressing.

Artificial selection is a powerful tool for promoting commercially important traits, like body size, nutrition profile, and mating capability. On the other hand, selection cannot create traits from nothing. All it can do is promote variants that already exist in a population, or work to remove them if they are less useful. This is why considerations such as starting population size and population diversity, which increase that chance that you have a beneficial variant in a population, are so important. Also, this imposes limitations on what artificial selection can or cannot achieve. It is unlikely, for example, that breeding trials alone will produce elephant-sized, photosynthesizing crickets. At some point, it becomes less costly to fulfill a certain function with a different species, rather than expending resources on adapting existing stock. For this reason, it may be important to expand commercial stock to accommodate a larger variety of waste inputs. This review paper describes the big three bio converters (BSF, cricket, mealworm), some alternative species (such as the codling moth and housefly), and recommendations for the development of new breeding programs.

In the traditional Darwinian model, pressure from the environment combined with resource scarcity results in slow changes to behavior and morphology (body shape). For example, with the beaks of finches adapting to the kind of food available on a given island by growing differently shaped beaks. Mendel, a contemporary of Darwin, showed that the inheritance of traits like beak length follows a mathematical pattern. For a long time, biologists understood that this was mediated by genetics and was a one-way flow from DNA (the manual) to RNA (the instructions) to proteins (the resulting product) which we call the central dogma. Recently, we have come to understand that there is a complex web of information exchange between each step. Epigenetics describes changes that don’t alter the DNA sequence but are stable and can be inherited. The epigenome is just as relevant as the genome when studying an insect. In fact, most domestication related changes in the short-term act on regulatory genes, which don’t code for proteins but can affect how an organism produces them. This paper reviews how epigenetics affects animal personality. Personality, used here to describe a predisposition to a certain set of behaviors, can affect things like feeding and mating activity that might, in turn, affect production.
Validating rearing techniques for individual rearing operations can ensure the most efficient production.

When wild species are introduced to a laboratory environment, changes are often observed in genetic diversity, gene expression, and microbiome composition. Not all genetic changes are bad, and some are deliberately selected for, but a reduction in diversity can also reduce fitness in species undergoing mass rearing. The BSF industry is new, but there are other species that IAB can look to as an example of what is to come or, in the case of this paper, what is happening now in industrial strains. When wild species are introduced to a laboratory environment, changes are often observed in genetic diversity, gene expression, and microbiome composition. Not all genetic changes are bad, and some are deliberately selected for, but a reduction in diversity is associated with reduced fitness, an effect called inbreeding depression. In addition to fitness costs, a small and homogeneous population is more vulnerable to genetic drift, which is the tendency of genes to either be fixed or lost in a population. These risks apply to any domesticated species but insects like the black soldier fly are especially vulnerable. They are r-selected species, which means that they produce many young and have very short lifespans. For example, it is possible to cycle through 6 full BSF generations in the time it takes for a cow to produce a calf. This allows for rapid changes in population characteristics. Knowledge on BSF genetics is scarce, though, and papers like this are critical to understanding best practices for genetic management and selective breeding.

The authors of this paper demonstrate that both wild and commercial black soldier fly populations largely separate into two lineages, with lineage a representing North American BSF and lineage b covering the rest. This information is useful in informing breeding practices, as population substructure can confound research results. For example, if lineage a BSF grow faster with a certain protein ratio, while lineage b grows slower, a trial that originates in North America might falsely predict optimal conditions when generalized to BSF in Europe or Asia. This paper also highlighted regions in the black soldier fly genome that should be of great interest to BSF breeders. They might be key factors driving success in captivity, like better growth or stronger immunity. On the other hand, these traits could also be part of what's known as 'domestication syndrome,' where certain negative characteristics, like reproductive problems or reduced immunity, appear. By investigating these candidate regions, we can identify which traits are beneficial and should be maintained in breeding programs, and which might be harmful and need to be carefully managed or bred out for the health and well-being of the species

Consider that kale, broccoli, and cabbage are derived from the same plant, each selected for a different trait and bred for many generations. Some traits are easy to measure, like body size or growth time, but even these “simple” traits are built upon many interacting proteins. To complicate the problem, many genes are passed on in blocks of DNA (recombination). If one selects for a gene involved in egg laying, they might also get a hitchhiking gene involved in wingspan, simply because it is physically close in the fly’s DNA. When wild species become domesticated, they experience changes in genes and gene expression. Some of these changes are deliberate, commercially desired traits. Others are unintended consequences of population bottle necks (starting with small number of individuals), relaxation of selective pressures (for example, more sterile rearing environment), or the hitchhiking of linked genes. Reduced genetic diversity is one common result of domestication. A small and homogeneous population is more vulnerable to genetic drift, which is the tendency of genes to either be fixed or lost in a population. Even if a gene is “good”, it can still be lost from a population through random chance if its frequency is low enough. The same is true for “bad” genes, which can become fixed even when they cause harm. In this case, the authors show one positive outcome of domestication; an increased sexual performance in domesticated males. Identifying which genes are under selection, and therefore responsible for the performance increase, could allow IAB to replicate the author’s success in other mass reared species.

Drosophila melanogaster, the fruit fly, is a model organism for genetics with a long history of research. Insights into black soldier fly genetics can be drawn from what is already known from its distant cousin. Like the black soldier fly and all other insects, fruit flies don’t have an adaptive immune system. They don’t have memory cells, for example, that allow for vaccines in vertebrates like pigs, chickens, and cows. As a result, research promoting pathogen tolerance must rely on improvements on the innate immune system. The authors show how 20-hydroxyecdysone (20E), which has homologs in the black soldier fly, works to regulate innate immunity in the fruit fly. The 20e gene is so highly networked that modifying it for improvement programs could create problems. Evidence in this review, though, suggests that manipulating its downstream targets could improve survival in the event of a pathogen outbreak in mass rearing.

Artificial selection is a powerful tool to alter an organism, but it comes with some challenges. If one selects strongly for a gene involved in egg laying, they might also get a hitchhiking gene variant with reduced disease tolerance, simply because the two genes are close together on the DNA strand. This is why insect breeding must be done with more care than picking out the fastest growing larvae. This study is relevant to insect growers because it highlights the potential impacts of elevated tropospheric ozone concentrations on plant communities and their associated insects and microbes. As insects often depend on plants for food and shelter, changes in plant communities can have significant effects on insect populations and their interactions with other organisms. The study suggests that elevated ozone concentrations can affect plant communities by altering their physiology, foliar chemistry, and volatiles, which can in turn affect plant-insect interactions and insect community composition. These effects can have indirect impacts on insect growers by reducing the availability and quality of insect food sources and altering insect pest populations. The study also notes that elevated ozone concentrations can disrupt plant-soil-microbe interactions, leading to changes in nutrient cycling and decomposition rates, which can have further implications for insect growers who rely on these processes for maintaining soil health and plant growth. Furthermore, the study identifies several regions with high endemic richness that are at high ozone risk by 2100, including parts of Asia and Africa, which are important regions for insect production and biodiversity. Thus, understanding the potential impacts of elevated ozone concentrations on plant communities and their associated insects and microbes is critical for insect growers to develop effective management strategies and maintain the health and productivity of their insect populations.

The study investigated the influence of gut bacteria on Drosophila melanogaster's fitness traits. It highlighted that interactions among bacteria play a crucial role in shaping host fitness, impacting aspects like development, reproduction, and lifespan. Through experiments with various combinations of five core gut bacteria, researchers discovered that bacterial diversity accelerated development, reproduction, and aging, although increased reproduction led to shorter lifespans. The study utilized mathematical models adapted from genetic epistasis to measure the impact of bacterial interactions on fly fitness. Results showed that higher diversity correlated with development and reproduction, whereas lifespan and microbiome abundances were highly reliant on bacterial species interactions. These interactions, detected in 13-44% of cases, influenced multiple traits, reflecting life history tradeoffs. The findings indicated that these interactions were context-dependent and held significant importance akin to individual bacterial species within gut microbiomes.

This study aimed to characterize the bacterial communities within the midguts of tsetse flies collected from various locations in Kenya and Uganda and explore their associations with African trypanosome infections. Utilizing both culture-dependent and independent methods, researchers isolated and sequenced bacterial strains from different tsetse species captured at distinct sites in Kenya. The obligate endosymbiont Wigglesworthia was identified as the most abundant bacterium within the midgut of G. pallidipes, persisting consistently regardless of trypanosome infection status. Additionally, Sodalis, a commensal symbiont, exhibited significantly higher densities in trypanosome-infected flies compared to uninfected ones. Field-captured G. pallidipes displayed distinct and low-density communities of environmentally acquired microbes in their midguts, with variations in taxonomic structure associated with parasite infection and geographic location. The findings contribute to a deeper understanding of the complex interactions between tsetse flies, their microbiota, and trypanosome vector competence, potentially guiding the development of innovative disease control strategies or enhancing existing ones.

The reporter will change the mealworm’s eye color or make it glow under a UV lamp, to tell the breeder that the GMO gene is actively expressed. This paper provides a valuable resource for researchers in insect agriculture to follow up on. The Darwinian concept of “survival of the fittest” is often misinterpreted in the context of single fit individual. The truth is that evolution acts on, and is evaluated based on, the genetics of a whole population. Progress of evolution is based on the mechanics of random chance as much as natural selection, too. If a version of a gene is present in low frequency, it is likely to be lost regardless of how fit it makes an individual. For example, consider a situation where one single male cricket was born with genes that made it twice as big, fast growing, and delicious as any other in the entire production facility (high fitness, low frequency allele). There’s a chance that the sheer number of competing males prevents it from mating at all. Consider what would happen if the mating line was not selected randomly, but instead they just grabbed a convenient clump of neonates within reach (population bottleneck/founder effect). The odds of the super cricket gene spreading becomes lower. What if there are much more males than females (skewed gender ratio) or if constant outbreeding introduces wild crickets (gene flow) that lack a supergene? What if all wild imported crickets have the supergene? These considerations and more are described in population genetics by the term “effective population size” or Ne. These factors affecting the realistic number of mating pairs, and how their genes spread through a population, must be considered as much as any environmental conditions or genetics modifications used to develop a trait.
